: ''For the wreath used in heraldry, see [[torse]].'' [[File:Christmas Wreath - geograph.org.uk - 639554.jpg|thumb|A [[Christmas]] wreath on a house door in England.]] [[File:Sofia - Odrysian Wreath from Golyamata Mogila.jpg|thumb|upright|A golden wreath and ring from the burial of an [[Odrysian]] Aristocrat at the Golyamata Mogila in the [[Yambol]] region of Bulgaria. Mid 4th century BC.]]
A '''wreath''' (''pronunciation'': /…πiÀêŒ∏/) is an assortment of [[flower]]s, [[Leaf|leaves]], [[fruit]]s, [[twig]]s, or various materials that are constructed to resemble a ring.<ref name="freedict">{{cite web| url= http://www.thefreedictionary.com/wreath|title=Wreath |publisher=The Free Dictionary By Farlex|accessdate=2012-05-19}}</ref>
In English-speaking countries, wreaths are used typically as household ornaments, mainly as an [[Christmas decoration|Advent and Christmas decoration]]. They are also used in ceremonial events in many cultures around the globe. They can be worn as a [[Corolla (chaplet)|chaplet]] around the head, or as a [[garland]] around the neck. Wreaths have much history and symbolism associated with them. They are usually made from [[evergreen]]s and symbolize strength, as evergreens last even throughout the harshest winters. [[Bay laurel]] may also be used, and these wreaths are known as [[laurel wreath]].
== Etymology ==
The word wreath comes from Middle English ''wrethe'' and from Old English ''writha'', ''band''.<ref name="freedict" />
== History ==
=== Ancient Etruscan wreaths ===
[[File:Ivy wreath BM 2296.jpg|thumb|Wreath with ivy leaves and berries, a [[satyr]]'s head at either end. Gold sheet, Etruscan artwork, 400‚Äì350 BC. From a tomb near [[Tarquinia]].]]
Wreaths were a design used in ancient times in southern Europe. The most well-known are pieces of [[Etruscan civilization]] jewelry, made of gold or other precious metals. Symbols from Greek myths often appear in the designs, embossed in precious metal at the ends of the wreath. Ancient Roman writers referred to Etruscan ''corona sutilis'', which were wreaths with their leaves sewn onto a background.<ref>{{cite book|last=Higgins|first=Reynold Alleyne|title=Greek and Roman Jewellery|year=1980|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-03601-7|pages=150}}</ref> These wreaths resemble a [[diadem]], with thin metal leaves being attached to an ornamental band.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Deppert-Lippitz|first1=Barbara|first2=Anne R. |last2=Bromberg|first3=John |last3=Dennis|title=Ancient gold jewelry at the Dallas Museum of Art|year=1996|publisher=Dallas Museum of Art in association with the University of Washington Press|isbn=978-0-936227-19-1|pages=39}}</ref> Wreaths also appear stamped into Etruscan medallions. The plants shown making the wreaths in Etruscan jewelry include ivy, oak, olive leaves, myrtle, laurel, wheat and vines.
Wreaths were worn as crowns by Etruscan rulers. The Etruscan symbolism continued to be used in Ancient Greece and Rome. Roman magistrates also wore golden wreaths as crowns, as a symbolic testament to their lineage back to Rome's early Etruscan rulers. Roman magistrates also used several other prominent Etruscan symbols in addition to a golden wreath crown: [[fasces]], a curule chair, a purple [[toga]], and an ivory rod.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hadas|first=Moses|title=A History of Latin Literature|year=1952|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=978-0-231-01848-7|pages=7}}</ref>
=== Ancient Greece and Rome === {{Seealso|Olive wreath|Laurel wreath}}
[[File:Apollo with his laurel wreath.jpg|thumb|upright|left|A replica bust of [[Apollo]] wearing a laurel wreath.]]
In the [[Greco-Roman world]], wreaths were used as an adornment that could represent a person‚Äôs occupation, rank, their achievements and status. The wreath that was commonly used was the [[laurel wreath]]. The use of this wreath comes from the [[Greek mythology|Greek myth]] involving [[Apollo]], Zeus‚Äô son and the god of life and light, who fell in love with the nymph [[Daphne]]. When he pursued her she fled and asked the river god [[Peneus]] to help her. Peneus turned her into a laurel tree. From that day, Apollo wore a wreath of laurel on his head. Laurel wreaths became associated with what Apollo embodied; victory, achievement and status and would later become one of the most commonly used symbols to address achievement throughout Greece and Rome. Laurel wreaths were used to crown victorious athletes at the original [[Olympic Games]]<ref name="Batchen 2006 92">{{cite book|last=Batchen|first=Geoffrey|title=Forget Me Not: Photography and Remembrance|year=2006|publisher=Princeton Architectural Press|isbn=978-1-56898-619-7|pages=92}}</ref> and are still worn in Italy by university students who just graduated.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pages.jh.edu/~gazette/2009/08june09/08saisgraduation.html |title=Crowning glories |accessdate=October 25, 2016 |quote=Six graduates of SAIS' Bologna Center joined the long tradition on May 29, when they, too, were crowned with the aromatic green wreaths.}}</ref>
Other types of plants used to make wreath crowns also had symbolic meaning. For example, [[oak]] leaves symbolized wisdom, and were associated with [[Zeus]], who according to Greek mythology made his decisions while resting in an oak grove. The [[Twelve Tables]], dating to 450 BC, refer to funeral wreaths as a long-standing tradition.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.constitution.org/sps/sps01_1.htm|title=The Laws of the Twelve Tables |accessdate=February 14, 2013 |quote=Anyone who has rendered himself deserving of a wreath ... shall have a right to have the said wreath placed upon his dead body}}</ref> [[Olive wreath]] was the prize for the winner at the [[ancient Olympic Games]].<ref>[http://odysseus.culture.gr/a/1/11/ga115.html ŒëœÅœáŒ±ŒØŒøŒπ ŒüŒªœÖŒºœÄŒπŒ±Œ∫ŒøŒØ ŒëŒ≥œéŒΩŒµœÇ: ŒüŒπ œÑŒπŒºŒ≠œÇ œÉœÑŒøœÖœÇ ŒüŒªœÖŒºœÄŒπŒøŒΩŒØŒ∫ŒµœÇ.]</ref>
== Modern wreaths ==
=== Harvest wreath ===
[[File:Harvest Wreath.jpg|thumb|left|150px|A Scandinavian-style harvest wreath made of woven straw.]]
{{multiple image|footer=A five-candle Advent wreath in the [[chancel]] of a Christian church (top) and a Christmas wreath adorning an American home, with the [[chalking the door|door chalked]] for Epiphanytide and the wreath hanger bearing a placard of the [[Angel Gabriel]] (bottom)|width=250|align=right|direction=vertical| image1=Advent Wreath of Saint Peter's Catholic Church.jpg|image2=Christmas wreath.jpg}}
Harvest wreaths, a common household decoration today, are a custom with ancient roots in Europe. The creation of harvest wreaths in Europe can be traced back to ancient times, and is associated with [[animistic]] spiritual beliefs. In Ancient Greece, the harvest wreath was a sacred amulet, using wheat or other harvested plants, woven together with red and white wool thread. The harvest wreath would be hung by the door year-round.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hastings|first=James|title=Encyclopedia of Religion and Ethics, Part 16|origyear=1916|year=2003|publisher=Kessinger Publishing|isbn=978-0-7661-3693-9|pages=778}}</ref>
Harvest wreaths were an important symbol to the community in Ancient Greece, not merely to the farmer and his family. The festivals devoted to [[Dionysus]], the [[Oschophoria]] and [[Anthesteria]], included a ritual procession called the ''eires√Æon√™''. A harvest wreath was carried to [[Pyanopsia]] and [[Thargelia]] by young boys, who would sing during the journey. The laurel or olive wreath would be hung at the door, and then offerings were made to [[Helios]] and the Hours. It was hoped that this ritual would bring protection against crop failure and plagues.<ref>{{cite book|last=Mitchell-Boyask|first=Robin|title=Plague and the Athenian imagination: drama, history and the cult of Asclepius|year=2008|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-87345-1|pages=50‚Äì1}}</ref>
In Poland, the harvest wreath (''wieniec'') is a central symbol of the Harvest Festival, ''Dozynki''. Wreaths are made of different shapes and sizes, using harvested grain plants, fruit and nuts. The wreath is then brought to a church for a blessing by a priest. The tradition includes a procession to the family home from the church, with a girl or young woman leading the procession and carrying the wreath. The procession is followed with a celebration and feast.<ref>{{cite book|last=Zamojska-Hutchins|first=Danuta|title=Cooking the Polish Way|year=2002|publisher=Lerner Publications|isbn=978-0-8225-4119-6|pages=16‚Äì17}}</ref> Ukraine, Hungary, and other Eastern Europe cultures also have similar rituals that began as part of pre-Christian culture.

The symbol for it is the Advent candlestick with four candles in it, and we light one more candle for each of the four Sundays before Christmas. Most people start putting up the Christmas decorations on the first of Advent.}}</ref> a custom that is sometimes done liturgically, through a [[hanging of the greens]] ceremony.<ref name="RiceHuffstutler2001">{{cite book|last1=Rice|first1=Howard L.|last2=Huffstutler|first2=James C.|title=Reformed Worship|date=1 January 2001|publisher=Westminster John Knox Press|language=English |isbn=9780664501471|page=197|quote=Another popular activity is the "Hanging of the Greens," a service in which the sanctuary is decorated for Christmas.}}</ref> The [[Advent wreath]] was first used by [[Lutheranism|Lutherans]] in Germany in the 16th century,<ref name="Colbert1996">{{cite book|last=Colbert|first=Teddy|title=The Living Wreath|year=1996|publisher=Gibbs Smith|isbn=9780879057008|quote=It is believed that the European advent wreath began as a Lutheran innovation in the sixteenth century.}}</ref> and in 1839, Lutheran priest [[Johann Hinrich Wichern]] used a wreath made from a cart wheel to educate children about the meaning and purpose of [[Christmas]], as well as to help them count its approach, thus giving rise to the modern version of the Advent wreath. For every Sunday of Advent, starting with the fourth Sunday before Christmas, he would put a white candle in the wreath and for every day in between he would use a red candle.<ref name="Mosteller2008">{{cite book|last=Mosteller|first=Angie |title=Christmas|year=2008|publisher=Itasca Books|language=English|isbn=9781607910084|pages=167|quote=The first clear association with Advent is generally attributed to German Lutherans in the 16th century. === Funeral and memorial wreaths ===
[[File:Cenotaph, Richmond Cemetery (07).JPG|thumb|left|A sculpted wreath on the [[South African War Memorial, Richmond Cemetery]]]]
[[File:World War I Memorial, Hamilton, Queensland 04.jpg|thumb|left|Wreaths laid at war memorials in Australia]]
[[File:People gathered at the grave of Andrei Sakharov, 1990.jpg|thumb|right|Wreaths are mounted on frames near the Moscow grave of Russian intellectual [[Andrei Sakharov]], 1990]]
The symbolism of wreaths has been used at funerals since at least the time of Ancient Greece, to represent a circle of eternal life. Evergreen wreaths were laid at the burial place of early Christian virgin martyrs in Europe, the evergreen representing the victory of the eternal spirit over death.<ref name="Batchen 2006 92"/>
In early modern England, a wreath custom existed for the funerals of "young maidens". A young woman of the same age as the one being mourned would lead the funeral procession, carrying a wreath of white flowers to represent the purity of the deceased, and "that eternal crown of glory reserved for her in heaven".<ref>{{cite book|last=Hulme|first=Frederick Edward|title=Bards and blossoms; or, The poetry, history, and associations of flowers|year=1877|publisher=Marcus Ward & Co|location=Oxford University|pages=50‚Äì1}}</ref>
By the Victorian era, the symbolism of flowers had grown to become an elaborate language, and the symbolism of funeral wreaths was no exception. Flowers represented life and resurrection. Specific flowers were used in funeral wreaths to represent particular sentiments. Cypress and willow were used for crafting wreath frames, and were associated with mourning by the Victorians.<ref name="Batchen 2006 92"/>
Wreaths are commonly laid at the tombs of soldiers and at memorial [[cenotaphs]] during [[Memorial Day]] and [[Remembrance Day]] ceremonies. Wreaths may also be laid in memory of persons lost at sea, either from an accident or due to navy action. In a memorial service at sea, the wreath is lowered to the water and set adrift.
== Wreaths worn as crowns == {{see also|Wreath (attire)}}
A wreath may be used as a [[headdress]] made from leaves, flowers and branches. It is typically worn in festive occasions and on [[holy days]]. Wreaths originally were made for use with [[pagan]] rituals in Europe, and were associated with the changing seasons and fertility. Christianity accepted the symbolism of the wreath based upon its Roman association with honour and moral virtue.<ref>{{cite book|last=Goody|first=Jack|title=The Culture of Flowers|year=1993|publisher=CUP Archive|isbn=978-0-521-41441-8|pages=201}}</ref> During the Middle Ages, Christian art featured depictions of the [[Virgin Mary]] and various saints crowned with wreaths, much as figures from Roman and Greek mythology were depicted wearing wreaths, as well as Roman and Greek rulers and heroes.
=== Maypole wreath ===
[[File:Maypole.JPG|thumb|upright|A [[Maypole]] with wreaths, raised for [[Midsummer]] celebrations in √ñstra Insj√∂, [[Dalarna|Dalarna, Sweden]]]]
Wreath customs in Europe have survived over many centuries. The observance of [[May Day]] in England includes [[Maypole]] festivities, culminating in a race by young unmarried men to climb to the top of the Maypole to capture the May Day wreath perched at the top of the pole. The winner of this contest would wear the wreath as his crown, and would be recognized as the May Day King for the rest of the holiday. Plants traditionally used to make Midsummer wreaths and garlands include white lilies, green [[birch]], [[fennel]], [[St. John's Wort]], [[Artemisia annua|wormwood]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/cropfactsheets/artemisia.pdf |title=Data sheet about Artemisia annua |publisher=[[Purdue University]] |last1=Ferreira |first1=Jorge |last2=Janick |first2=Jules |year=2009 |accessdate=24 August 2013}}</ref> [[vervain]] and [[flax]]. The flowers used in making the [[Midsummer]] wreath had to be picked early in the morning before the dew had dried; the belief was that once the dew dried, the magical properties of the plants evaporated with the dew.<ref>{{cite book|last=Simmons|first=Adelma Grenier|title=A world of wreaths from Caprilands: the legend, lore, and design of traditional herbal wreaths|year=1994|publisher=JG Press|isbn=978-1-57215-000-3|pages=17}}</ref>
[[Midsummer]] celebrations are still observed in Germany and Scandinavia as well, with Maypoles and wreaths playing a prominent role, similar to England.
=== Wreath symbolism in England ===
By the [[Renaissance]] period, wreaths became symbols of political and religious alliances in England. Protestant reformers such as the Puritans saw wreaths and the holidays they were associated with, such as May Day, as being [[pagan]] corrupting influences that destroyed healthy Christian morality. Soldiers confiscated wreaths in Oxford on May Day of 1648.<ref name="Goody">{{cite book|last=Goody|first=Jack|title=The Culture of Flowers|year=1993|publisher=CUP Archive|isbn=978-0-521-41441-8|pages=202}}</ref> During the [[Interregnum]] following the overthrow of [[Charles I of England]], wreaths symbolized Royalist sympathies. In [[Bath, Somerset]], the coronation of [[Charles II of England]] was marked with a procession of 400 maidens in white and green, carrying "gilded crowns, crowns made of flowers, and wreaths made of laurel mixed with tulips", and led by the mayor's wife.<ref name="Goody" />
[[File:Ivan Kupala Day in Serebryany bor 2017 50.jpg|thumb|<!-- Wreath symbolism -->Wreath thrown in water on [[Ivan Kupala Day]] Feast of St. John the Baptist, in Russia]]
=== Saint Lucy's Day crown ===
[[Saint Lucy]] is traditionally depicted in Christian artwork wearing a wreath as a crown, and on the wreath stand lit candles symbolizing the light of the world represented by Christ. Sweden in particular has a long history of observing [[Saint Lucy's Day]] (St. Lucia's Day). "St. Lucia's crowns", made of a brass wreath holding candles, are part of the customs associated with this holiday.<ref>{{cite book|last=Simmons|first=Adelma Grenier|title=A world of wreaths from Caprilands: the legend, lore, and design of traditional herbal wreaths|year=1994|publisher=JG Press|isbn=978-1-57215-000-3|pages=69}}</ref>
